NOTICE OF PROBABLE VIOLATION 
and 
PROPOSED COMPLIANCE ORDER

metadata.1: others

others

G. Clark White 
Executive Vice President Operations 
Targa Downstream LLC 
811 Louisiana Street Suite 2100 
Houston TX, 77002

metadata.1: others

__data__.text: Dear Mr. White:

metadata.1: others
others

__data__.text:
From February 22 to October 17, 2022, a representative of the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials 
Safety  Administration  (PHMSA),  pursuant  to  Chapter  601  of  49  United  States  Code  (U.S.C.

metadata.1: others
others

__data__.text:
As  a  result  of  the  inspection,  it  is  alleged  that  Targa  has  committed  probable  violations  of  the 
Pipeline Safety Regulations, Title 49, Code of Federal Regulations (CFR).

metadata.1: others

__data__.text:
The items inspected 
and the probable violations are:

metadata.1: others
§ 195.402 Procedural Manual for Operations, Maintenance, and Emergencies

__data__.text: § 195.402 Procedural manual for operations, maintenance, and emergencies.

metadata.1: § 195.402 Procedural Manual for Operations, Maintenance, and Emergencies

__data__.text: (a)  General.

metadata.1: § 195.402 Procedural Manual for Operations, Maintenance, and Emergencies

__data__.text:
Each  operator  shall  prepare  and  follow  for  each 
pipeline system a manual of written procedures for conducting normal 
operations  and  maintenance  activities  and  handling  abnormal 
operations and emergencies.

metadata.1: § 195.402 Procedural Manual for Operations, Maintenance, and Emergencies

__data__.text:
This manual shall be reviewed at intervals 
not  exceeding  15  months,  but  at  least  once  each  calendar  year,  and 
appropriate  changes  made  as  necessary  to  insure  that  the  manual  is 
effective.

metadata.1: § 195.402 Procedural Manual for Operations, Maintenance, and Emergencies

__data__.text:
This manual shall be prepared before initial operations of a 
pipeline  system  commence,  and  appropriate  parts  shall  be  kept  at 
locations where operations and maintenance activities are conducted.

metadata.1: § 195.402 Procedural Manual for Operations, Maintenance, and Emergencies

__data__.text: (c) Maintenance and normal  operations.

metadata.1: § 195.402 Procedural Manual for Operations, Maintenance, and Emergencies

__data__.text:
The manual  required by 
paragraph (a) of this section must include procedures for the following 
to provide safety during maintenance and normal operations:

metadata.1: § 195.402 Procedural Manual for Operations, Maintenance, and Emergencies
§ 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas
§ 195.402 Procedural Manual for Operations, Maintenance, and Emergencies

__data__.text:
(13) Periodically reviewing the work done by operator personnel to 
determine the effectiveness of the procedures used in normal operation 
and  maintenance  and  taking  corrective  action  where  deficiencies  are 
found.

metadata.1: § 195.402 Procedural Manual for Operations, Maintenance, and Emergencies

__data__.text:
Targa  failed  to  follow  its  manual  of  written  procedures  for  conducting  normal  operations  and 
maintenance  activities  and  handling  abnormal  operations  and  emergencies  in  accordance  with 
§ 195.402(a)  and  Targa  failed  to  include  the  procedures  required  by  §  195.402(c)(13).

metadata.1: § 195.402 Procedural Manual for Operations, Maintenance, and Emergencies

__data__.text:
Specifically,  Targa  failed  to  conduct  periodic  reviews  of  work  done  by  operator  personnel  to 
determine the effectiveness of the procedures used in normal operation and maintenance and take 
corrective action where deficiencies were found in accordance with § 195.402(c)(13).

metadata.1: § 195.402 Procedural Manual for Operations, Maintenance, and Emergencies

__data__.text:
During the inspection, PHMSA requested records associated with periodic reviews of the work 
done by operator personnel for the calendar year 2020, 2021 and 2022.

metadata.1: § 195.402 Procedural Manual for Operations, Maintenance, and Emergencies

__data__.text:
Targa failed to provide 
records of any periodic reviews.

metadata.1: § 195.402 Procedural Manual for Operations, Maintenance, and Emergencies

__data__.text:
Further, Targa’s Hazardous Liquid OM&E – Operations & Maintenance Manual (Aug. 13, 2010) 
failed to include an adequate procedure for periodically reviewing the work done by personnel to 
determine the effectiveness of procedures in accordance with § 195.402(c)(13).

metadata.1: § 195.402 Procedural Manual for Operations, Maintenance, and Emergencies

__data__.text:
This procedure 
failed to include details on how the work done by operator personnel is reviewed to determine 
effectiveness of procedures, and how the results of the reviews is documented.

metadata.1: § 195.402 Procedural Manual for Operations, Maintenance, and Emergencies

__data__.text:
Therefore,  Targa  failed  to  follow  its  manual  of  written  procedures  for  conducting  normal 
operations  and  maintenance  activities  and  handling  abnormal  operations  and  emergencies  in 
accordance with § 195.402(a) & (c)(13).

metadata.1: § 195.402 Procedural Manual for Operations, Maintenance, and Emergencies
§ 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text: § 195.452 Pipeline integrity management in high consequence areas.

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas
§ 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text: (j)  What  is  a  continual  process  of  evaluation  and  assessment  to

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text: maintain a pipeline's integrity?

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text: (1) General.

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text:
After completing the baseline integrity assessment, an 
operator must continue to assess the line pipe at specified intervals and 
periodically evaluate the integrity of each pipeline segment that could 
affect a high consequence area.

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text:
Targa failed to periodically evaluate the integrity of each pipeline segment that could affect a high 
consequence area (HCA) in accordance with § 195.452(j)(1) and Targa failed to have and follow 
procedures implementing § 195.452(j)(1) in accordance with § 195.402(c)(3).

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text:
Specifically, Targa 
failed  to  conduct  a  periodic  evaluation  for  the  Davis  pump  station  in  Murray  County,  OK  and 
failed to provide a process in its integrity management plan to periodically evaluate the integrity 
of each pipeline segment that could affect an HCA.

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text:
During the inspection, Targa failed to provide records of a periodic evaluation for the Davis pump 
station in Murray County, OK.  Targa provided a spreadsheet for the Akoma to Velma segment 
but  it  failed  to  address  specific  risk  factors  and  analysis  for  this  facility.

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text:
The  record  failed  to 
demonstrate that a periodic evaluation was performed to address the risk associated with the Davis 
pump facility, which is in an HCA.

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text: Targa’s Integrity Management Plan for Liquids Transmission Pipelines Section 7.1 (Apr.

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text:
1, 2020) 
failed to include provisions for periodic evaluations of each pipeline segment that could affect an 
HCA.

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text: Rather, this section only included the assessment process for line pipe at specified intervals.

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text:
The procedure failed to provide details on how the periodic evaluation would be conducted for 
pump station facility.

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text:
Therefore, Targa failed to periodically evaluate the integrity of each pipeline segment that could 
affect a high consequence area (HCA) in accordance with § 195.452(j)(1) and Targa failed to have 
and follow procedures implementing § 195.452(j)(1) in accordance with § 195.402(c)(3).

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text: Proposed Compliance Order

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text: Under 49 U.S.C.

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text:
§ 60122 and 49 CFR § 190.223, you are subject to a civil penalty not to exceed 
$257,664 per violation per day the violation persists, up to a maximum of $2,576,627 for a related 
series of violations.

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text:
For violation occurring on or after March 21, 2022 and before January 6, 
2023, the maximum penalty may not exceed $239,142 per violation per day the violation persists, 
up to a maximum of $2,391,412 for a related series of violations.

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text:
For violation occurring on or 
after May 3, 2021 and before March 21, 2022, the maximum penalty may not exceed $225,134 
per violation per day the violation persists, up to a maximum of $2,251,334 for a related series of 
violations.

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text:
For  violation  occurring  on  or  after  January  11,  2021  and  before  May  3,  2021,  the 
maximum penalty may not exceed $222,504 per violation per day the violation persists, up to a 
maximum of $2,225,034 for a related series of violations.

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text:
For violation occurring on or after July 
31,  2019  and  before  January  11,  2021,  the  maximum  penalty  may  not  exceed  $218,647  per 
violation  per  day the  violation  persists,  up to  a maximum  of  $2,186,465  for  a related  series  of 
violations.

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text:
For violation occurring on or after November 27, 2018 and before July 31, 2019, the 
maximum penalty may not exceed $213,268 per violation per day, with a maximum penalty not to 
exceed $2,132,679.

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text: For violation occurring on or after November 2, 2015 and before November

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text:
27, 2018, the maximum penalty may not exceed $209,002 per violation per day, with a maximum 
penalty not to exceed $2,090,022.

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text:
We have reviewed the circumstances and supporting documents involved in this case, and have 
decided not to propose a civil penalty assessment at this time.

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text: With respect to Items 1 and 2 pursuant to 49 U.S.C.

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text:
§ 60118, the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials 
Safety Administration proposes to issue a Compliance Order to Targa.

metadata.1: § 195.452 Pipeline Integrity Management in High Consequence Areas

__data__.text:
Please refer to the Proposed 
Compliance Order, which is enclosed and made a part of this Notice.

Be 
advised that all material you submit in response to this enforcement action is subject to being made

metadata.1: Response to this Notice

__data__.text:
If  you  believe  that  any  portion  of  your  responsive  material  qualifies  for 
confidential treatment under 5 U.S.C.

metadata.1: Response to this Notice

__data__.text:
§ 552(b), along with the complete original document you 
must provide a second copy of the document with the portions you believe qualify for confidential 
treatment redacted and an explanation of why you believe the redacted information qualifies for 
confidential treatment under 5 U.S.C.

metadata.1: Response to this Notice
Response to this Notice

__data__.text:
Following the receipt of this Notice, you have 30 days to  respond as described in the enclosed 
Response Options.

metadata.1: Response to this Notice

__data__.text:
If you do not respond within 30 days of receipt of this Notice, this constitutes 
a  waiver  of  your  right  to  contest  the  allegations  in  this  Notice  and  authorizes  the  Associate 
Administrator for Pipeline Safety to find facts as alleged in this Notice without further notice to 
you and to issue a Final Order.

metadata.1: Response to this Notice

__data__.text:
If you are responding to this Notice, we propose that you submit 
your correspondence to my office within 30 days from receipt of this Notice.

metadata.1: Response to this Notice

__data__.text:
The Region Director 
may extend the period for responding upon a written request timely submitted demonstrating good 
cause for an extension.

metadata.1: Response to this Notice

__data__.text:
In  your  correspondence  on  this  matter,  please  refer  to  CPF  4-2023-044-NOPV  and,  for  each 
document you submit, please provide a copy in electronic format whenever possible.

metadata.1: Response Options for Pipeline Operators in Enforcement Proceedings

__data__.text: PROPOSED COMPLIANCE ORDER

metadata.1: Response Options for Pipeline Operators in Enforcement Proceedings

__data__.text:
Pursuant  to  49  United  States  Code  §  60118,  the  Pipeline  and  Hazardous  Materials  Safety 
Administration  (PHMSA)  proposes to  issue  to Targa  Downstream, LLC (Targa)  a Compliance 
Order incorporating the following remedial requirements to ensure the compliance of Targa with 
the pipeline safety regulations:

metadata.1: Response Options for Pipeline Operators in Enforcement Proceedings

__data__.text: A.

metadata.1: Response Options for Pipeline Operators in Enforcement Proceedings

__data__.text: B.

metadata.1: Response Options for Pipeline Operators in Enforcement Proceedings

__data__.text: C.

metadata.1: Response Options for Pipeline Operators in Enforcement Proceedings

__data__.text:
In regard to Item 1 of the Notice pertaining to Targa’s failure to conduct periodic 
reviews of work done by operator personnel to determine the effectiveness of the 
procedures used in normal operation and maintenance, and take corrective action 
where deficiencies were found and failure to establish a proper procedure for the 
same,  Targa  must  amend  its  procedures  to  include  provisions  for  periodically 
reviewing the work done by operator personnel to determine the effectiveness of 
the  procedures  used  in  normal  operation  and  maintenance  and  taking  corrective 
action where deficiencies are found within 30 days of issuance of the Final Order.

metadata.1: Response Options for Pipeline Operators in Enforcement Proceedings

__data__.text:
In  regard  to  Item  2  of  the  Notice  pertaining  to  Targa’s  failure  to  periodically 
evaluate the integrity of each pipeline segment that could affect a high consequence 
area,  Targa  must  develop  a  procedure  in  its  integrity  management  plan  to 
periodically evaluate the integrity of each pipeline segment that could affect a high 
consequence  area  within  30  days  of  issuance  of  the  Final  Order.

metadata.1: Response Options for Pipeline Operators in Enforcement Proceedings

__data__.text:
Targa  must 
perform  the  periodic  evaluation  of  Davis  pump  station  facility  and  submit  the 
evaluation to the Director, Southwest Region within 60 days of issuance of the Final 
Order.

metadata.1: Response Options for Pipeline Operators in Enforcement Proceedings

__data__.text:
It  is  requested  (not  mandated)  that  Targa  maintain  documentation  of  the  safety 
improvement costs associated with fulfilling this Compliance Order and submit the 
total  to  Bryan  Lethcoe,  Director,  Southwest  Region,  Pipeline  and  Hazardous 
Materials Safety Administration.

metadata.1: Response Options for Pipeline Operators in Enforcement Proceedings

__data__.text:
It is requested that these costs be reported in two 
categories: 1) total cost associated with preparation/revision of plans, procedures, 
studies and analyses, and 2) total cost associated with replacements, additions and 
other changes to pipeline infrastructure.
